Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Large: Collaborative Research:Programmable Inter-Domain Observation and Control

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Internet is an essential part of modern society, playing a vital role in a wide range of educational, commercial, military, and social activities. However, network operators today have a limited ability to observe and control the paths used to carry traffic across the Internet. For example, although it is often beneficial for several networks to cooperate-e.g., a content provider and cellular network jointly picking the best paths from content to customers-existing Internet routing protocols make it difficult to share information or collaborate to select routes. These limitations contribute to a host of problems, including decreased path stability, degraded performance, and service outages.

This project will develop a system called IN-CONTROL that aggregates information from participating networks and active measurements into an inter-domain network information base (iNIB). The iNIB presents operators with a unified interface for making observations about global forwarding paths and a rich control interface for issuing requests to steer traffic along preferred paths. To build the iNIB, the project is focusing on the following tasks: (i) developing provenance-based techniques to obtain reliable results from computations performed over potentially-untrustworthy data (ii) designing deployable mechanisms for observing and controlling Internet forwarding paths, and (iii) building a scalable implementation that incorporates optimizations to reduce resource demands for answering iNIB queries. The intellectual merit of this research lies in developing reliable abstractions for observing and controlling Internet forwarding paths and a scalable implementation that can be readily deployed on the current Internet.

The broader impacts include reducing the fragility of the Internet, and broadening the interdisciplinary community of researchers working on problems related to inter-domain networking. This project also provides research experiences for undergraduate students and members of under-represented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the course of this project, we invented a number of technologies designed to make networks and networked systems more reliable, easier to manage, and more secure.

The first intellectual contribution of this project was a high-performance implementation of a network configuration language called NetKAT. NetKAT has a number of features that make it easier for network operators to describe complex network behaviors. However, earlier implementations of NetKAT suffered performance problems that made it impractical. We designed new algorithms and data structures that significantly improve the performance of NetKAT. A number of other researchers have since employed this system in their work. We released our work as open-source software (available as part of the Frenetic project, at http://frenetic-lang.org). We published an award-winning research paper on this work.

The second intellectual contribution of this project was an investigation of new approaches for updating the software on network controllers. Software updates are necessary to release new features, fix problems, or address security vulnerabilities. Updates are difficult and annoying even on single computers, but they are particularly hard for network controllers, since people expect networks to be ?always on?. We developed a new approach for network controller update based on ?state transfer? and showed that it can make several kinds of updates occur more smoothly. We published a research paper on this work.

The third intellectual contribution of this project was the development of new technologies for working with system configurations. We focused on Puppet, which is one of the most widely-used system configuration languages in industry. We developed the first configuration verification tool for Puppet, which finds errors in system configurations. We also developed an approach that helps system administrators ensure that the computer systems that they manage are consistent with their configurations. Both of these tools are available as open-source software (https://plasma.cs.umass.edu/rehearsal and https://plasma.cs.umass.edu/tortoise). We published two papers on this work, one of which received a ?distinguished artifact award? for its accompanying software system.

The fourth intellectual contribution of this project was an investigation of what is known as ?serverless computing?. Serverless computing is a new approach to cloud computing that is designed to be significantly cheaper and easier for programmers. Our work shows that there are several subtle issues that arise in serverless computing that can lead to incorrect results and data loss. Our work establishes the mathematical foundations needed to address these problems rigorously. We also designed and implemented new serverless computing features that make certain programs significantly faster and cheaper in serverless computing environments. We released the code for this project as open-source software (https://plasma.cs.umass.edu/lambda-lambda). We published an award-winning paper on this work.

We also engaged in significant outreach activities aimed at educating both students and our academic colleagues.

1. PI Guha helped organized two well-attended workshops on topics at the intersection of programming languages and networking (PLVnet 2015 and NetPL 2016).

2. PI Guha was invited to give a keynote talk on the aforementioned work at the 2018 International Symposia on Implementation and Application of Functional Languages, held in Lowell, MA.

3. PI Guha co-organized a workshop for high-school students in Holyoke, MA that introduced them to programming and robotics.
